sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Allergic condition: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Allergic condition: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Asthma: (moderate and severe exacerbation; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 40 to 80 mg/day ORALLY in 1 or 2 divided doses until PEF reaches 70% of predicted or personal best; outpatient burst, 40 to 60 mg ORALLY in 1 or 2 divided doses for a total of 3-10 days
  • Asthma: (long-term therapy; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 7.5 to 60 mg ORALLY daily in the morning or every other day as needed for control of asthma
  • Bacterial corneal ulcer: (1% solution) 1 drop instilled into affected eye 4 times per day for 1 week, then twice daily for 1 week, then once daily for 1 week (study dosing); initiate within 3 days of starting topical antibiotic therapy
  • Breast cancer: Optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Acute exacerbations: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Acute exacerbations: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of endocrine system: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of endocrine system: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of eye: (ophthalmic) 1 or 2 drops into conjunctival sac up to every hour during the day and every 2 hours at night as necessary, can gradually reduce to 1 drop three times a day depending upon response
  • Disorder of eye: (oral) unresponsive to topical corticosteroids, suspension, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of eye: (oral) unresponsive to topical corticosteroids, orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of hematopoietic structure: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of hematopoietic structure: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of respiratory system: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of respiratory system: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of skin: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Disorder of skin: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Exacerbation of multiple sclerosis: 200 mg/day ORALLY for 1 wk, followed by 80 mg every other day for 1 month
  • Fever, due to malignancy: Optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Hodgkin's disease: 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Hodgkin's disease: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Hodgkin's disease: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Inflammatory disorder: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Inflammatory disorder: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Intracranial tumor, Primary: Optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Leprosy - Nerve injury: 40 mg/day ORALLY for 2 weeks, 30 mg/day for 2 weeks, 20 mg/day for 2 weeks, 15 mg/day for 2 weeks, 10 mg/day for 2 weeks, and 5 mg/day for 2 weeks.
  • Multiple myeloma: Optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Neoplastic disease: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Neoplastic disease: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Nephrotic syndrome: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Nephrotic syndrome: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Prostate cancer: Optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Transplanted organ rejection, Acute or chronic: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Transplanted organ rejection, Acute or chronic: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Trichinosis, With neurologic or myocardial involvement: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Trichinosis, With neurologic or myocardial involvement: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Tuberculosis of meninges, With subarachnoid or impending block OR enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes causing respiratory difficulty OR pleural or pericardial effusion: solution, 5 to 60 mg/day ORALLY
  • Tuberculosis of meninges, With subarachnoid or impending block OR enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes causing respiratory difficulty OR pleural or pericardial effusion: orally disintegrating tablet, 10 to 60 mg/day ORALLY

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Allergic condition: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 3 to 4 divided doses (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day)
  • Asthma: (moderate and severe exacerbation, 11 yr and younger; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 1 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 2 divided doses (maximum 60 mg/day) until PEF reaches 70% of predicted or personal best; outpatient burst, 1 to 2 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 2 divided doses (maximum 60 mg/day) for a total of 3-10 days
  • Asthma: (long-term therapy, 11 yr and younger; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 0.25 to 2 mg/kg ORALLY daily in the morning or every other day as needed for control of asthma
  • Asthma: (moderate and severe exacerbation, 12 yr and older; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 40 to 80 mg/day ORALLY in 1 or 2 divided doses until PEF reaches 70% of predicted or personal best; outpatient burst, 40 to 60 mg ORALLY in 1 or 2 divided doses for a total of 3-10 days
  • Asthma: (long-term therapy, 12 yr and older; NHLBI asthma guidelines) 7.5 to 60 mg ORALLY daily in the morning or every other day as needed for control of asthma
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Acute exacerbations: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of endocrine system: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of eye: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of hematopoietic structure: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of respiratory system: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Disorder of skin: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 3 to 4 divided doses (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day)
  • Hodgkin's disease: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Inflammatory disorder: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Leprosy - Nerve injury: 1 mg/kg/day ORALLY for 1 month followed by 0.5 mg/kg/day for 3 months with further reductions of 5 mg over a month thereafter for 6 to 8 months
  • Neoplastic disease: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Nephrotic syndrome: 60 mg/m(2) ORALLY daily divided 3 times/day for 4 wk, then 40 mg/m(2) every other day for 4 wk
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Transplanted organ rejection, Acute or chronic: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Trichinosis, With neurologic or myocardial involvement: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses
  • Tuberculosis of meninges, With subarachnoid or impending block OR enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes causing respiratory difficulty OR pleural or pericardial effusion: 0.14 to 2 mg/kg (4 to 60 mg/m(2) per day) ORALLY daily divided into 3 or 4 doses

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatrics: start therapy at low end of dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Allergic condition
  • Asthma
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Acute exacerbations
  • Disorder of endocrine system
  • Disorder of eye
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract
  • Disorder of hematopoietic structure
  • Disorder of respiratory system
  • Disorder of skin
  • Exacerbation of multiple sclerosis
  • Hodgkin's disease
  • Hodgkin's disease
  • Inflammatory disorder
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system
  • Neoplastic disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Transplanted organ rejection, Acute or chronic
  • Trichinosis, With neurologic or myocardial involvement
  • Tuberculosis of meninges, With subarachnoid or impending block OR enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes causing respiratory difficulty OR pleural or pericardial effusion
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Bacterial corneal ulcer
  • Breast cancer
  • Croup (Mild to Moderate)
  • Cytarabine adverse reaction - Disorder of cornea
  • Fever, due to malignancy
  • Idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Intracranial tumor, Primary
  • Kawasaki disease
  • Leprosy - Nerve injury
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Prostate cancer
  • Pulmonary eosinophilic granuloma
  • Viral respiratory infection

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• systemic fungal infections
  • hypersensitivity to prednisoLONE or its components
  • live of live attenuated vaccines (immunosuppresive doses)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cirrhosis
  • diverticulitis
  • fluid disturbances, use caution in hypertention, CHF, renal insufficiency
  • hypothyroidism
  • measles, chickenpox and other infections
  • myasthenia gravis
  • ocular herpes simplex
  • osteoporosis
  • peptic ulcer
  • pregnancy
  • psychotic tendencies
  • smallpox vaccine and other immunization
  • tuberculosis, active or latent
  • ulcerative colitis
  • untreated systemic infections

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Prednisolone: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Prednisolone: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Prednisolone: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension
  • Dermatologic:Finding of skin healing, Impaired
  • Endocrine metabolic:Decreased body growth, Hyperglycemia
  • Gastrointestinal:Increased appetite, Upset stomach, Weight increased
  • Immunologic:At risk for infection
  • Musculoskeletal:Osteoporosis, Especially in elderly
  • Neurologic:Insomnia
  • Psychiatric:Depression, Euphoria, Mood swings
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Adrenal insufficiency, Cushing's syndrome, Drug-induced adrenocortical insufficiency, HPA
  • Ophthalmic:Cataract, Glaucoma

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: PrednisoLONE sodium phosphate is a synthetic adrenocortical steroid that predominantly exerts glucocorticoid effects like promotion of gluconeogenesis, increased deposition of glycogen in the liver, inhibition of the utilization of glucose, anti-insulin activity, increased protein catabolism, increased lipolysis, stimulation of fat synthesis and storage, and increased urate and calcium excretion. The drug reduces eosinophil and lymphocyte production, stimulates erythropoiesis and production of polymorphonuclear lymphocytes and inhibits inflammation and wound healing. It induces the secretion of gastric juice components and possesses a slight mineralocorticoid activity.

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono: Renal: as sulfate and glucuronide conjugates

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • orally disintegrating tablet should not be removed from blister packet until just prior to administration
  • orally disintegrating tablet, peel open blister pack, place orally disintegrating tablet on tongue and either swallow whole or allow to dissolve in the mouth (with or without water)
  • orally disintegrating tablet, do not cut, split, or break for the tablets are friable

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• clinical improvement in inflammatory condition
  • creatinine kinase levels; especially in patients with neuromuscular transmission disorders (eg, myasthenia gravis), high doses of corticosteroids, or concomitant neuromuscular blocking agents (eg, pancuronium)
  • 24-hour urine for calcium and creatinine measurement; in patients on more than 4 continuous weeks or more than four 7-day bursts of corticosteroids per year
  • serum potassium; at regular intervals during prolonged therapy; especially patients with hypertension, congestive heart failure, or renal insufficiency
  • sodium levels in patients with hypertension, congestive heart failure, or renal insufficiency
  • cornea or sclera perforation, corneal ulceration, lack of clinical improvement or worsening of inflammatory condition; intraocular pressure, visual acuity, field of vision, cataract formation, and secondary infections especially with prolonged use (ophthalmic)
  • slit lamp microscopy; in patients with herpes simplex keratitis involving the stroma (ophthalmic)
  • dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) for bone density; patients on corticosteroids for more than 4 continuous weeks or more than four 7-day bursts per year (oral).
  • growth and development of infants and children especially in patients on prolonged therapy (oral)
  • intestinal perforation monitoring; in nonspecific ulcerative colitis if there is a probability of perforation, abscess or other pyogenic infection, diverticulitis, fresh intestinal anastomosis or active or latent peptic ulcer (oral)
  • ophthalmic exams may be warranted especially with prolonged oral corticosteroid use due to an increased risk of subcapsular cataracts, glaucoma, and secondary ocular infections; patients with ocular herpes simplex there is possibility of corneal perforation (oral)
  • psychic derangements including euphoria, insomnia, mood swings, personality changes, severe depression, and frank psychosis; existing emotional instability or psychotic tendencies may be exacerbated (oral)
  • reactivation of latent tuberculosis or tuberculin reactivity; especially in patients on prolonged therapy (oral).
  • signs of infection since new infections may develop and there may be a decreased resistance to localize the infection (oral)
  • urinalysis, 2-hr postprandial blood glucose, blood pressure, body weight, and chest x-ray, at regular intervals; especially with prolonged therapy (oral)

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Ophthalmic Solution: 1 %
    • Oral Solution: 5 MG/5 ML, 15 MG/5 ML, 25 MG/5 ML
    • Oral Tablet, Disintegrating: 10 MG, 15 MG, 30 MG
  • Millipred
    Oral Solution: 10 MG/5 ML
  • Orapred ODT
    Oral Tablet, Disintegrating: 10 MG, 15 MG, 30 MG
  • Orapred
    Oral Solution: 15 MG/5 ML
  • Pediapred
    Oral Solution: 5 MG/5 ML
  • Prednisol
    Ophthalmic Solution: 1 %
  • Veripred 20
    Oral Solution: 20 MG/5 ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
USES: Antiinflammatory agents used to treat a variety of clinical conditions, including adrenal insufficiency, asthma, various allergy disorders, and autoimmune disorders (eg, hemolytic anemia, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus). Corticosteroids are available in oral, parenteral, inhalational, and topical formulations. PHARMACOLOGY: Multiple mechanisms of action including anti-inflammatory activity, immunosuppressive properties, and antiproliferative actions. Anti-inflammatory effects result from decreased formation, release and activity of the mediators of inflammation (eg, kinins, histamine, liposomal enzymes, prostaglandins, leukotrienes) which reduced the initial manifestations of the inflammatory process. The immunosuppressive properties decrease the response to delayed and immediate hypersensitivity reactions (eg, type III and type IV). The antiproliferative effects reduce hyperplastic tissue characteristic of psoriasis. TOXICOLOGY: Corticosteroids decrease calcium absorption, increase calcium excretion, and inhibit osteoblast formation, leading to a decrease in bone formation and an increase in bone resorption, thereby contributing to the development of osteoporosis. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Acute toxicity following overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion is rarely a clinical problem. Acute adrenal insufficiency rarely reported after overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Cardiac dysrhythmias (ie, atrial fibrillation)(methylPREDNISolone), seizures (methylPREDNISolone), anaphylaxis. CHRONIC EXPOSURE: Cushingoid appearance, muscle wasting and weakness, hypertension, hyperglycemia, subcapsulary cataracts and glaucoma, osteoporosis, psychosis. ABRUPT WITHDRAWAL: Dysphoria, irritability, emotional liability, depression, fatigue, anxiety, depersonalization, myalgia, and arthralgia.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Seizures have been reported with IV pulse methylPREDNISolone therapy. If seizures occur, administer IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Serious toxicity is not expected after ingestion of corticosteroids alone, and prehospital gastrointestinal decontamination is not routinely required. HOSPITAL: Significant toxicity is not expected after overdose; gastrointestinal decontamination is generally not necessary. Activated charcoal should be considered after extremely large ingestions or if more toxic coingestants are involved.
  • Airway management: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required in patients with severe allergic reactions, but this is rare.
  • Antidote: None
  • Acute allergic reaction: MILD/MODERATE: Monitor airway. Administer antihistamines with or without inhaled beta agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. SEVERE: Oxygen, aggressive airway management, antihistamines, epinephrine, corticosteroids, ECG monitoring and IV fluids.
  • Monitoring of patient: Routine laboratory studies are not likely to be necessary after acute overdose. Serum electrolytes and glucose are useful to assess for adverse effects from chronic therapy. Monitor vital signs, fluid and electrolyte status as indicated. Monitor neurologic status as indicated in symptomatic patients. Plasma concentrations are not readily available or clinically useful in the management of overdose.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are UNLIKELY to be of value because of the high degree of protein binding and large volume of distribution.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with a minor unintentional exposure who are asymptomatic or have mild symptoms can likely be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Moderate to severely symptomatic patients and those with deliberate overdose should be sent to a healthcare facility for evaluation and treated until symptoms resolve. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate treatment should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
TOXICITY: Acute ingestion is rarely a clinical problem; effects rarely occur with administration of less than three weeks duration. An adolescent ingested 30 mg dexamethasone and subsequently developed acute adrenal insufficiency. Patient recovered following administration of methylPREDNISolone. CHRONIC EXPOSURE: Six infants (aged 3 to 8 months) who were treated with large amounts (up to 10 tubes for 1.5 to 5 months) of topical corticosteroids for diaper dermatitis developed Cushing's syndrome and adrenocortical insufficiency. Hepatomegaly and hepatosteatosis were observed in 5 and 3 patients, respectively. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with drug and indication.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patients using oral form to avoid vaccines during therapy.
  • This drug may cause impaired skin healing, decreased body growth in pediatric patients, peptic ulcer, depression, euphoria, cataract, or glaucoma.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report fever, signs/symptoms of infection, or exposure to measles, chickenpox or other viral infections.
  • This drug may cause hyperglycemia. Advise diabetic patients to report problems with glycemic control during prednisone therapy.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of adrenocortical insufficiency or hypercortisolism (fatigue, muscle weakness, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, low blood pressure), especially if on prolonged therapy.
  • Advise patients taking oral form against sudden discontinuation of drug.
  • Instruct patients using ophthalmic form on proper instillation technique. Patient should not wear contact lenses during therapy unless approved by healthcare professional.
